channel.title: J. Krishnamurthi on The Outsider's Journey
channel.description: Recent content in J. Krishnamurthi on The Outsider's Journey

item.title: SVL 1.11: The City of Angels and San Diego
item.description: 6th December 2014 Hi Everyone, On Sunday night we returned from a memorable and wonderful trip to southern California. Since ‘Merricans celebrate Thanksgiving on the fourth Thursday of November, it becomes a long weekend perfect for travel.

item.title: Thoughts about going Vegan
item.description: I was raised vegetarian and my family has been vegetarian for generations. When I was thirteen or fourteen, my parents told me that since I will be travelling when I get older, I could start getting used to meat if I wanted to.

item.title: Reflections on God 6: Radical Atheism
item.description: This is part of God Flux but split into smaller sections for an easier read. Radical Atheism After almost a year of intense email exchanges about god with my friend in Sydney, I went to Edinburgh for my Masters in Neuroscience.

item.title: Reflections on God 4: Hindu Mythology and Philosophy
item.description: This is part of God Flux but split into smaller sections for an easier read. Ka, Doniger, Joseph Campbell Before entering the waters of atheism again, let me mention the other influences I had during and a little after my undergraduate years.

item.title: Reflections on God 3: The Other Cheek of Christianity
item.description: This is part of God Flux but split into smaller sections for an easier read. The other cheek of Christianity During my undergraduate course, I joined the choir and sang songs praising Jesus.

item.title: Reflections on God 2: Deep Ecology and Buddhism
item.description: This is part of God Flux but written in smaller sections for an easier read. Compassion So I put together my own version of god. Almost an imaginary friend.

item.title: God Flux; Reflection on a Spiritual Journey
item.description: I have wondered about the concept of god all my life so far. I would like to describe and reflect on my journey so far.

item.title: Path
item.description: March 2002 . From where we come, we go back But where do we go in the middle? We follow a path, A path that is not there.

item.title: Existence
item.description: From December 2007 I think that wasting time is criminal. Somehow, there has to be a purpose to everything. And when there is none, I feel like I don’t deserve to exist.

item.title: At the Neem Tree
item.description: August 12, 2007 . . I walk to my Friends in silence, Drop my bag and jacket on the way Carelessly let loose my hair.

item.title: The First and Last Freedom (TFALF) 3: Thoughts during "Individual and Society"
item.description: Is the individual an instrument of society or does the society exist for the individual? In the first paragraph K creates this black and white sense of options.

item.title: The First and Last Freedom 2: Thoughts during 'What are we seeking?'
item.description: What do we want in life? Many people would say ‘to be happy’. K asks whether we know the difference between happiness and gratification. He says:

item.title: The First and Last Freedom: Thoughts during Chapter 1
item.description: Different approaches are necessary for different types of books; Novels and most popular science books are meant to be read cover to cover. Dictionaries, encyclopedias and other factual texts are meant to be looked up for specific information.

item.title: Dialogues III
item.description: Dear readers, I’ve finally started to shed my inertia and write properly again. Here is the next set of Dialogues we had. J: Just to clarify, was it the Old Testament which said the earth was flat?

item.title: Dialogues II
item.description: S: In response to your questions: What is relativism? It’s the philosophical position that all points of view are equally valid and that all truth is relative to the individual.

item.title: Dialogues I
item.description: I have a friend who I found last September after nearly 9 years of no contact. We initially had no idea that we would become close again.
